stories.text:
My 5-year old daughter asked me a few days back, how the fist human came to be.

I gave the Darwinian answer: "She (aribrary gender) was born from an ape mother."

Today, she came back, after obviously having thought about this, and asked: "Who was the father of the children of the first human?"

Now this was more difficult. We could just say that anyone born to her species born after day X were human, and those before were apes. But if we chose to use genotypes or phenotypes to determine this, "she" may very well have mated with someone just short of meeting the criteria, and may also have had children that qualified as "apes".

What do I answer the 5-year-old?

stories.text:
Jun 17: Eliot's BRIEF NARRATIVE

Risked His Scalp in Prayer

John Eliot put his life at the mercy of the r*n[0] to get them to listen to his preachings. He wrote vividly about his settlements of Christian Indians. Now villages and Indians have disappeared. Only his story remains.

Read: Eliot's BRIEF NARRATIVE

Vol. 43, pp. 138-146 (Download Link Here: http://www.myharvardclassics.com/downloads/20120213_28/download)

Please comment below on your own thoughts and feeling towards the reading.

Note: I am not affiliated in any way with myharvardclassics.com. They just have free downloads of .pdfs of the volumes is all.

[0] Woah! Right? I'm editing the slur for now as that's what the original text says. I'm expecting a lively discussion on race with this reading, so please be aware of it and it's meanings to Native Americans: https://law.marquette.edu/facultyblog/2013/12/why-is-the-word-redskin-so-offensive/comment-page-1/
stories.title: Jun 17: Eliot's Brief Narrative
